translated: It is said, Indeed, nothing uneaten is eaten by him, for the purpose of praising the knowledge that all this is the food of Prāṇa, which has been enjoined.

analyzed: tena eka vākya tā āpatteḥ
translated: Because it thus becomes syntactically connected with that.

analyzed: na tu śāsra antara vihitasya bādhane sāmarthyam anya paratvāt asya
translated: But it does not have the power to override what is enjoined by another scripture, because this (verse) has a different purpose.

original: prāṇamātrasya sarvamannamityetaddarśanamihi vidhitsitaṃ na tu sarvaṃ bhakṣayediti /
analyzed: prāṇa mātrasya sarvam annam iti etat darśanam ihi vidhitsitam na tu sarvam bhakṣayet iti
translated: Here, the view that all this is the food of Prāṇa alone is intended to be enjoined, not that one should eat everything.

analyzed: yat tu sarva bhakṣaṇe doṣa abhāva jñānam sat mithyā eva pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: And the knowledge that there is no fault in eating everything, if it exists, is false, because there is no valid means of knowledge (to establish it).

original: viduṣaḥ prāṇatvātsarvānnopapatteḥ sāmarthyādadoṣa eveti cet / na /
analyzed: viduṣaḥ prāṇa tvāt sarva anna upapatteḥ sāmarthyāt adoṣaḥ eva iti ced na
translated: If it be said that there is no fault, because the wise man is the vital air, and because of the possibility of all food, and because of capability, [we say] no.

analyzed: aśeṣa anna tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the possibility of eating all food is not possible.

original: satyaṃ yadyapi vidvānprāṇo yena kāryatakaraṇasaṃghātena viśiṣṭasya vidvattā tena kāryakaraṇasaṃghātena kṛmikīṭadevādyaśeṣānnabhakṣaṇaṃ nopapadyate🔽tena tatrāśeṣānnabhakṣaṇe doṣābhāvajñāpanamanarthakam /
analyzed: satyam yadi api vidvān prāṇaḥ yena viśiṣṭasya vidvat tā tena kārya karaṇa saṃghātena kṛmi kīṭa deva ādi aśeṣa anna bhakṣaṇam na upapadyate  tena tatra aśeṣa anna bhakṣaṇe doṣa abhāva jñāpanam anarthakam
translated: It is true that the wise man is the vital air, and by that aggregate of instruments and objects with which the wise man is distinguished, the eating of all food, worms, insects, gods, etc., is not possible.🔽Therefore, the teaching of the absence of fault in eating all food there is useless.

analyzed: aprāpta tvāt aśeṣa anna bhakṣaṇa doṣasya
translated: Because the fault of eating all food is not obtained.

analyzed: nanu prāṇaḥ san bhakṣayati eva kṛmi kīṭa ādi annam api
translated: But being the vital air, he certainly eats even the food of worms, insects, etc.

analyzed: bāḍham
translated: Certainly.

original: kintu na tadviṣayaḥ pratiṣedho 'sti /🔽tasmāddaivaraktaṃ kiṃśukaṃ tatra doṣābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: kintu na tad viṣayaḥ pratiṣedhaḥ sti  tasmāt daiva raktam kiṃśukam tatra doṣa abhāvaḥ
translated: But there is no prohibition regarding that.🔽Therefore, the red kinshuka tree of the gods, there is the absence of fault.

analyzed: atas tad rūpeṇa doṣa abhāva jñāpanam anarthakam
translated: Therefore, the teaching of the absence of fault in that form is useless.

analyzed: aprāpta tvāt aśeṣa anna bhakṣaṇa deṣasya
translated: Because the fault of eating all food is not obtained.

original: yena tu kāryakaraṇasaṃghātasambandhena pratiṣedhaḥ kriyate tatsambandhena tviha naiva pratiprasavo 'sti /
analyzed: yena tu kārya karaṇa saṃghāta sambandhena pratiṣedhaḥ kriyate tad sambandhena tu iha na eva pratiprasavaḥ asti
translated: But by that connection with the aggregate of instruments and objects by which the prohibition is made, there is no exception here by that connection.

original: tasmāttatpratiṣedhātikrame doṣa eva syādanyaviṣayatvānna ha vā ityādeḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt tad pratiṣedha atikrame doṣaḥ eva syāt anya viṣaya tvāt na ha vā ityādeḥ
translated: Therefore, if one transgresses that prohibition, there would indeed be a fault, because the statement 'he does not' etc. refers to something else.

original: na ca brāhmaṇādiśarīrasya sarvānnatvadarśanamiha vidhīyate kintu prāṇamātrasyaiva /
analyzed: na ca brāhmaṇa ādi śarīrasya sarva anna tva darśanam iha vidhīyate kintu prāṇa mātrasya eva
translated: And here it is not enjoined that the body of a Brahmin etc. should eat all food, but only of the mere life-breath.

original: yathā ca sāmānyena sarvānnasya prāṇasya kiñcidannajātaṃ kasyacijjīvanahetuḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca sāmānyena sarva annasya prāṇasya kiñcid anna jātam kasyacid jīvana hetuḥ
translated: And just as for the life-breath which in general eats all food, some kind of food is the cause of life for some,

original: yathā viṣaṃ viṣajasya krimestadevānyasya prāṇānnamapi saddṛṣṭameva doṣamutpādayati maraṇādilakṣaṇam /
analyzed: yathā viṣam viṣa jasya krimeḥ tat eva anyasya prāṇa annam api sat dṛṣṭam eva doṣam utpādayati maraṇa ādi lakṣaṇam
translated: just as poison is for a certain kind of worm, and that same food for another is life-breath, but when seen produces a fault characterized by death etc.

original: tathā sarvānnasyāpi prāṇasya pratiṣiddhānnabhakṣaṇe brāhmaṇatvādidehasaṃbandhāddoṣa eva syāt /
analyzed: tathā sarva annasya api prāṇasya pratiṣiddha anna bhakṣaṇe brāhmaṇa tva ādi deha saṃbandhāt doṣaḥ eva syāt
translated: Similarly, for the life-breath which eats all food, there would indeed be a fault in eating forbidden food, due to the connection with the body of a Brahmin etc.

analyzed: tasmāt mithyā jñānam eva abhakṣya bhakṣaṇe doṣa abhāva jñānam
translated: Therefore, the knowledge of the absence of fault in eating what should not be eaten is indeed false knowledge.

analyzed: āpaḥ vāsaḥ iti āpaḥ bhakṣamāṇāḥ vāsaḥ sthānīyāḥ tava
translated: 'Water is your garment' - the water you eat is like a garment for you.

original: atra ca prāṇasyā'po vāsa ityetaddarśanaṃ vidhīyate /
analyzed: atra ca prāṇasya apaḥ vāsaḥ iti etat darśanam vidhīyate
translated: And here the view that water is the garment of the life-breath is enjoined.

original: na tu vāsaḥkārye āpo viniyoktuṃ śakyāḥ /
analyzed: na tu vāsaḥ kārye āpaḥ viniyoktum śakyāḥ
translated: But water cannot be employed in the function of a garment.

analyzed: tasmāt yathāprāpte bbhakṣaṇe darśana mātram kartavyam
translated: Therefore, in the eating of water as it is obtained, only the view should be performed.

original: na ha vā asya sarvaṃ prāṇasyānnamityevaṃvido 'nannamanadanīyaṃ jagdhaṃ bhuktaṃ na bhavati ha /
analyzed: na ha vai asya sarvam prāṇasya annam iti evaṃvidaḥ nannam a nadanīyam jagdham bhuktam na bhavati ha
translated: For one who knows thus, nothing is not food for the vital breath; nothing eaten or consumed becomes uneaten or undrinkable.

original: yadyapyanenānadanīyaṃ bhuktamadanīyameva bhuktaṃ syānna tu tatkṛtadoṣeṇa lipyata ityetadvidyāstutirityavocāma /
analyzed: yadi api anena anadanīyam bhuktam adanīyam eva bhuktam syāt na tu tad kṛta doṣeṇa lipyate iti etat vidyā stutiḥ iti avocāma
translated: Even if he eats what is undrinkable, it becomes drinkable when eaten, and he is not tainted by the fault of eating it. This is praise of the knowledge, we have said.

original: tathā nānannaṃ pratigṛhītaṃ yadyapyapratighrāhyaṃ hastyādi pratigṛhītaṃ syāttadapyannameva
analyzed: tathā na anannam pratigṛhītam yadi api a pratighrāhyam hasti ādi pratigṛhītam syāt tat api annam eva
translated: Similarly, nothing is not accepted as food; even if he accepts what is not to be accepted, such as an elephant, etc., it becomes food.

original: pratigrāhyaṃ syāttatrāpyapratigrāhyapratigrahadoṣeṇa na lipyata iti stutyarthameva
analyzed: pratigrāhyam syāt tatra api a pratigrāhya pratigraha doṣeṇa na lipyate iti stuti artham eva
translated: It becomes acceptable, and he is not tainted by the fault of accepting what is not to be accepted. This is for the purpose of praise alone.

analyzed: yaḥ evam etat anasya prāṇasya annam veda
translated: One who thus knows the food of this vital breath,

original: phalaṃ tu prāṇātmabhāva eva na tvetatphalābhiprāyeṇa kiṃ tarhi stutyabhiprāyeṇeti /
analyzed: phalam tu prāṇa ātma bhāvaḥ eva na tu etat phala abhiprāyeṇa kim tarhi stuti abhiprāyeṇa iti
translated: but the result is the state of the vital breath-self, not with the intention of a result, but rather with the intention of praise.

analyzed: nanu etat eva phalam kasmāt na bhavati
translated: But why is this not the result itself?

analyzed: na prāṇa ātma darśinaḥ prāṇa ātma bhāvaḥ eva phalam
translated: For one who sees the vital breath as the self, the state of the vital breath-self is not the result.

analyzed: tatra ca prāṇa ātma bhūtasya sarvātmanaḥ nadanīyam api ādyam eva
translated: And for him, even what is undrinkable becomes the first food itself, for one who has become the vital breath-self and the all-self.

analyzed: tathā a pratigrāhyam api pratigrāhyam eva iti yathāprāptam eva upādāya vidyā stūyate
translated: Similarly, even what is not to be accepted is accepted. Taking it as it is obtained, the knowledge is praised.

analyzed: atas nā eva phala vidhi sarūpa tā vākyasya
translated: Therefore, the sentence is not similar to an injunction of result.

original: yasmādāpo vāsaḥ prāṇasya tasmādvidvāṃso brāhmaṇāḥ śrotriyā adhītavedā aśiṣyanto bhokṣyamāṇā ācāmantyapo 'śitvā'cāmanti bhuktyā cottarakālamapo
analyzed: yasmāt āpaḥ vāsaḥ prāṇasya tasmāt vidvāṃsaḥ brāhmaṇāḥ śrotriyāḥ adhīta vedāḥ a śiṣyantaḥ bhokṣyamāṇāḥ ācāmanti apaḥ śitvā ācāmanti bhuktyā ca uttara kālam apaḥ
translated: Since water is the garment of the life-breath, therefore learned Brahmins, who have studied the Vedas, while eating, sip water before eating, and after eating, they sip water again.

analyzed: bhakṣayanti
translated: They consume water.

original: tatra teṣāmācāmatāṃ ko 'bhiprāya ityāhaetamevānaṃ prāṇamanagnaṃ kurvanto manyante /
analyzed: tatra teṣām ācāmatām kaḥ bhiprāyaḥ iti āha etam eva ānam prāṇam anagnam kurvantaḥ manyante
translated: There, what is the intention of those who sip water? It is said: They think they are making that life-breath unclothed.

original: asti caitadyoyasmai vāso dadāti sa tamanagnaṃ karomīti hi manyate /

analyzed: prāṇasya ca āpaḥ vāsaḥ iti hi uktam

original: yadapaḥ pibāmi tatprāṇasya vāso dadāmīti vijñānaṃ kartavyamityevamarthametat /
analyzed: yat apaḥ pibāmi tat prāṇasya vāsaḥ dadāmi iti vijñānam kartavyam iti evamartham etat
translated: The knowledge should be performed thus: When I drink water, I give a garment to the life-breath.

analyzed: nanu bhokṣyamāṇaḥ bhuktavān ca prayataḥ bhaviṣyāmi iti ācāmati
translated: But one who is about to eat and who has eaten sips water thinking I will be pure.

original: tatra ca prāṇasyānagnatākaraṇārthatve ca dvikāryatā'camanasya syāt /
analyzed: tatra ca prāṇasya anagna tā karaṇa artha tve ca dvi kārya tā ācamanasya syāt
translated: And if the purpose of sipping water is to make the life-breath unclothed, then the sipping would have two purposes.

analyzed: na ca kārya dvayam ācamanasya ekasya yuktam

analyzed: yadi prāyatya artham na anagnatā artham atha anagnatā artham na prāyatya artham
translated: If it is for the purpose of purification, not for the purpose of being without fire, or if it is for the purpose of being without fire, not for the purpose of purification.

analyzed: yasmāt evam tasmāt dvitīyam ācamana antaram prāṇasya anagna tā karaṇāya bhavatu na
translated: Since this is so, let the second sipping of water be for the purpose of making the breath without fire. No.

analyzed: kriyā dvi tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because the existence of two acts is possible.

original: dve hyete kriye bhotryamāṇasya bhuktavataśca yadācamanaṃ smṛtivihitaṃ tatprāyatyārthaṃ bhavati /

original: tatra cā'camanāṅgabhūtāsvapsu vāsovijñānaṃ prāṇasyetikartavyatayā codyate na tu tasminkriyamāṇa ācamanasya prāyatyarthatā vādhyate kriyāntaratvādācamanasya

translated: And in that, the knowledge of water as the garment of the breath is enjoined as something to be done by the breath, but when that sipping of water is being done, the purpose of purification of the sipping of water is not contradicted, because the sipping of water is a different act.
